technical_concept:
chmod — changes file permissions. chmod +x script.sh makes a file executable.
curl — transfers data from URLs. Great for testing APIs and downloading files.
wget — downloads files directly to disk.
history — shows your recent commands. Use !42 to re-run command #42.
alias — creates shortcuts: alias ll="ls -la" lets you type ll instead.
top — shows running processes and resource usage, like a task manager.

code_example.code:
chmod +x deploy.sh     # Make script executable
./deploy.sh             # Run it

curl https://api.example.com/data
wget https://example.com/file.zip

history                 # Show recent commands
!42                     # Re-run command #42

alias gs='git status'   # Create shortcut
alias ll='ls -la'       # Another shortcut

top                     # Live process viewer (q to quit)

challenge.task: This is a discussion lesson — no grading. Tell me: which of these tools (chmod, curl, wget, history, alias, top) do you think you'd use most in your daily work, and why?
challenge.hint: There's no wrong answer! Think about what you do most in your daily work.

dialogue.line: You've built shelter, gathered resources, learned to track and filter. Now let's fill your utility belt with the remaining tools. These are the ones you'll reach for in specific situations.

'chmod' controls permissions — who can read, write, or execute a file. 'chmod +x script.sh' makes a script runnable. Without it, the system won't let you execute your own tools. It's like sharpening a blade before use.
What about getting things from outside?

'curl' fetches data from URLs — APIs, web pages, files. It's your long-range communication tool. 'wget' is simpler — point it at a URL, it downloads the file. Think of curl as a radio and wget as a supply drop.

'history' shows every command you've typed — your field journal. 'alias' creates shortcuts for long commands — 'alias fire="echo building fire"' means less typing. And 'top' is your watchtower — it shows all running processes, CPU usage, memory. Your situational awareness dashboard.
So which of these would be most useful day to day?
That depends on your mission. A scripter lives by chmod. An API developer breathes curl. A power user swears by aliases. What would YOU reach for most?
Final briefing on your remaining gadgets, Ghost. These are specialist tools — each one has a specific use case.
'chmod' — permission control. 'chmod +x script.sh' arms a script for execution. Without it, your custom tools are just text files. Every operative needs to make their scripts executable.

'curl' — your encrypted comms channel. It talks to web APIs, downloads data, sends requests with custom headers. Perfect for C2 communication. 'wget' is the simpler cousin — point and download. Good for grabbing files from drop servers.

'history' logs every command you've typed — useful for retracing steps, dangerous if left behind. 'alias' creates cover names for commands — 'alias scan="nmap -sV"' means your keystrokes look innocent. And 'top' is your surveillance feed — shows every running process. Know what's running and you'll never be surprised.
Good arsenal. Which ones are mission-critical?
Depends on the operation. Every heist is different. What tools would you prioritize for your kind of work?
